entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub.

Quick Start

Create a new post

More info: Writing

Run server

More info: Server

Generate static files

More info: Generating

Deploy to remote sites

More info: Deployment

entry.title: Leetcode#116.Â Populating Next Right Pointers in Each Node
entry.content:
Problem

You are given aÂ perfect binary treeÂ where all leaves are on the same level, and every parent has two children. The binary tree has the following definition:

Populate each next pointer to point to its next right node. If there is no next right node, the next pointer should be set toÂ NULL.

Initially, all next pointers are set toÂ NULL.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the tree is in the rangeÂ [0, 212 - 1].
  • 1000 <= Node.val <= 1000

Follow-up:

  • You may only use constant extra space.
  • The recursive approach is fine. You may assume implicit stack space does not count as extra space for this problem.

Solve

top-down recursive

ç°¡åŒ–ä¸€é»

entry.title: Leetcode#120.Â Triangle
entry.content:
[leetcode62]

Problem

Given aÂ triangleÂ array, returnÂ the minimum path sum from top to bottom.

For each step, you may move to an adjacent number of the row below. More formally, if you are on indexÂ iÂ on the current row, you may move to either indexÂ iÂ or indexÂ i + 1Â on the next row.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Constraints:

  • 1 <= triangle.length <= 200
  • triangle[0].length == 1
  • triangle[i].length == triangle[i - 1].length + 1
  • -10^4 <= triangle[i][j] <= 10^4

Solve

use recursion

O(2^n) time, O(n) space

O(n^2) time, O(n^2) space

use dp(# èˆ‡ recursion ä¸åŒ ï¼Œrecursion æ˜¯å¾ä¸Šå¾€ä¸‹æ¨ï¼Œdp æ˜¯å¾ä¸‹å¾€ä¸Šæ¨)

O(n^2) time
O(n^2) space

çœ‹åˆ°æœ€ç°¡ä¾¿çš„

O(n^2) time

O(1) space

entry.title: Leetcode#117.Â Populating Next Right Pointers in Each Node II
entry.content:
leetcode116

Problem

Given a binary tree

Populate each next pointer to point to its next right node. If there is no next right node, the next pointer should be set toÂ NULL.

Initially, all next pointers are set toÂ NULL.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Constraints:

  • The number of nodes in the tree is in the rangeÂ [0, 6000].
  • 100 <= Node.val <= 100

Follow-up:

  • You may only use constant extra space.
  • The recursive approach is fine. You may assume implicit stack space does not count as extra space for this problem.

Solve

entry.title: Leetcode#121.Â Best Time to Buy and Sell Stock
entry.content:
Problem

You are given an arrayÂ pricesÂ whereÂ prices[i]Â is the price of a given stock on theÂ ithÂ day.

You want to maximize your profit by choosing aÂ single dayÂ to buy one stock and choosing aÂ different day in the futureÂ to sell that stock.

ReturnÂ the maximum profit you can achieve from this transaction. If you cannot achieve any profit, returnÂ 0.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Constraints:

  • 1 <= prices.length <= 10^5
  • 0 <= prices[i] <= 10^4

Solve

O (n) time and O(1) space

O (n) time and O(1) space

entry.title: Leetcode#146.Â LRU Cache
entry.content:
Problem

Design a data structure that follows the constraints of aÂ Least Recently Used (LRU) cache.

Implement theÂ LRUCacheÂ class:

  • LRUCache(int capacity)Â Initialize the LRU cache withÂ positiveÂ sizeÂ capacity.
  • int get(int key)Â Return the value of theÂ keyÂ if the key exists, otherwise returnÂ 1.
  • void put(int key, int value)Â Update the value of theÂ keyÂ if theÂ keyÂ exists. Otherwise, add theÂ key-valueÂ pair to the cache. If the number of keys exceeds theÂ capacityÂ from this operation,Â evictÂ the least recently used key.

The functionsÂ getÂ andÂ putÂ must each run inÂ O(1)Â average time complexity.

Example 1:

Constraints:

  • 1 <= capacity <= 3000
  • 0 <= key <= 10^4
  • 0 <= value <= 10^5
  • At mostÂ 2 * 10^5Â calls will be made toÂ getÂ andÂ put.

Solve

é¡Œç›®çµ¦çš„ LRU æ˜¯ä¸€å€‹å„²å­˜å™¨(ç·©å­˜å™¨)

æœ‰æ”¾å…¥ æ‹¿å‡ºåŠŸèƒ½

æ”¾å…¥æ™‚ï¼Œå¦‚æœè¶…éå®¹é‡ï¼Œå°±è¦æŠŠæœ€ä¹…æ²’æœ‰è¢«ä½¿ç”¨çš„è³‡æ–™ç§»é™¤

æˆ‘é€™é‚Šè¡¨ç¤º cache å‰å¾Œ é—œä¿‚ç‚º èˆŠè³‡æ–™ï¼Œå¾Œé¢ç‚ºæ–°è³‡æ–™

é¡Œç›®è¦æ±‚çš„ Hash Table Doubly-Linked List

ä½†python dict å¯ä»¥è®Šæœ‰åº !!!

å¯ä»¥åƒ list é€™æ¨£åš

ä½†list æœå°‹æ˜¯ç”¨ for

æ™‚é–“è¤‡é›œç‚ºO(n)ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥å¤±æ•—

ç”¨list forè¿´åœˆï¼Œä½†æ•ˆèƒ½ä¸Šæœ‰å•é¡Œ O(n) (å¤±æ•—)

æ™‚é–“è¤‡é›œåº¦: O(n)

é‚è¼¯æ²’éŒ¯ ä½†æ˜¯ æ™‚é–“è·‘å¤ªä¹…

åˆ©ç”¨iter(dict) ç‚ºæœ‰åºçš„(python 3.7~)

åœ¨ Python 3.7 ä¹‹å¾Œï¼Œ**dict** åœ¨ä¿ç•™æ’å…¥é †åºæ–¹é¢æ˜¯æœ‰åºçš„ã€‚å› æ­¤ï¼Œ**iter(self.dict)** è¿”å›çš„è¿­ä»£å™¨å°‡æŒ‰ç…§éµï¼ˆkeyï¼‰æ’å…¥çš„é †åºä¾†è¿­ä»£å­—å…¸ä¸­çš„éµã€‚

æ™‚é–“è¤‡é›œåº¦:O(1)

  • iterator : è¿­ä»£å™¨æ˜¯ Python ä¸­ä¸€ç¨®ç‰¹æ®Šçš„ç‰©ä»¶ï¼Œå®ƒå…è¨±éæ­·ï¼ˆè¿­ä»£ï¼‰å®¹å™¨ä¸­çš„å…ƒç´ ï¼Œè€Œä¸éœ€è¦äº‹å…ˆçŸ¥é“å®¹å™¨çš„çµæ§‹ã€‚å­—å…¸ã€åˆ—è¡¨ã€å…ƒçµ„ç­‰å¯è¿­ä»£çš„å®¹å™¨éƒ½å¯ä»¥é€šé iter() å‡½æ•¸è½‰æ›æˆè¿­ä»£å™¨ã€‚
  • iter() å‡½æ•¸ï¼šç”¨æ–¼å°‡å¯è¿­ä»£çš„å®¹å™¨ï¼ˆå¦‚å­—å…¸ã€åˆ—è¡¨ã€å…ƒçµ„ç­‰ï¼‰è½‰æ›æˆè¿­ä»£å™¨ç•¶ä½¿ç”¨è¿­ä»£å™¨æ™‚ï¼Œæˆ‘å€‘å¯ä»¥ä½¿ç”¨ next() å‡½æ•¸ä¾æ¬¡å–å¾—å®¹å™¨ä¸­çš„å…ƒç´ ã€‚
  1. **iter(self.dict)**ï¼šé€™ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†å°‡å­—å…¸ self.dict è½‰æ›ç‚ºä¸€å€‹è¿­ä»£å™¨ã€‚é€™æ˜¯å› ç‚ºå­—å…¸æœ¬èº«ä¸¦ä¸æ˜¯ä¸€å€‹è¿­ä»£å™¨ï¼Œä½†æˆ‘å€‘å¸Œæœ›èƒ½å¤ é€ä¸€è¨ªå•å…¶ä¸­çš„éµã€‚
  2. **next(iter(self.dict))**ï¼šé€™ä¸€éƒ¨åˆ†ä½¿ç”¨ next() å‡½æ•¸å–å¾—è¿­ä»£å™¨ iter(self.dict) ä¸­çš„ä¸‹ä¸€å€‹å…ƒç´ ï¼ˆé€™è£¡æ˜¯å­—å…¸ä¸­çš„ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹éµï¼‰ã€‚æ›å¥è©±èªªï¼Œå®ƒè¿”å›å­—å…¸ä¸­çš„ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹éµã€‚

å·åƒæ­¥ã€ç›´æ¥è¼‰å…¥æœ‰åºçš„dict

entry.title: Leetcode#201.Â Bitwise AND of Numbers Range
entry.content:
Problem

Given two integersÂ leftÂ andÂ rightÂ that represent the rangeÂ [left, right], returnÂ the bitwise(ä½å…ƒé‹ç®—) AND of all numbers in this range, inclusive.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Example 3:

Constraints:

  • 0 <= left <= right <= 2^31 - 1

Solve

å°å€é–“çš„æ•¸å­—é€²è¡Œä½å…ƒé‹ç®—

ä¸éé¡Œç›®è¦é€£çºŒ

å…ˆèªªçµè«–ã€å¯¦éš›çœ‹ å°±æ˜¯çœ‹ä½å…ƒæ•¸æœ‰æ²’æœ‰ä¸€æ¨£

å› ç‚ºé€£çºŒå€é–“ ä½å…ƒ AND çš„çµæœè©²ä½å…ƒæœƒæ˜¯ 0ã€‚

æ‰€ä»¥åªæœ‰é•·åº¦ä¸€æ¨£æ™‚ï¼Œæ‰æœ‰

ç¯„ä¾‹ä¸€

ç•¶ left = 5ã€right = 7 æ™‚

è¿´åœˆé–‹å§‹ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡å³ç§» left å’Œ right ä¸€ä½ï¼ŒåŒæ™‚å¢åŠ  shift çš„å€¼ã€‚

ç¬¬ä¸€æ¬¡è¿´åœˆï¼š

ç¬¬äºŒæ¬¡è¿´åœˆï¼š

è¿´åœˆçµæŸï¼Œå› ç‚ºæ­¤æ™‚ left ç­‰æ–¼ **right**ã€‚

æœ€å¾Œï¼Œå°‡ left å·¦ç§» shift ä½ï¼š

æ‰€ä»¥ï¼Œåœ¨å€é–“ [5, 7] å…§çš„æ‰€æœ‰æ•¸å­—çš„ä½å…ƒ AND é‹ç®—çµæœç‚º **4**ã€‚

é€™å€‹æ–¹æ³•é€šéå³ç§»é‚Šç•Œä¾†é€æ¼¸ç¸®å°å€é–“çš„ç¯„åœï¼ŒåŒæ™‚ä½¿ç”¨ shift è®Šæ•¸è·Ÿè¸ªå³ç§»çš„ä½å…ƒæ•¸ã€‚æœ€å¾Œï¼Œå°‡å·¦é‚Šç•Œå·¦ç§»å›ä¾†ï¼Œå¾—åˆ°ä½å…ƒ AND é‹ç®—çš„çµæœã€‚

ç¯„ä¾‹äºŒ

å‡è¨­ **left = 3ã€right = 8**ã€‚

è¿´åœˆé–‹å§‹ï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡å³ç§» left å’Œ right ä¸€ä½ï¼ŒåŒæ™‚å¢åŠ  shift çš„å€¼ã€‚

entry.title: Leetcode#427.Â Construct Quad Tree
entry.content:
Problem

Given aÂ n * nÂ matrixÂ gridÂ ofÂ 0'sÂ andÂ 1'sÂ only. We want to representÂ gridÂ with a Quad-Tree.

ReturnÂ the root of the Quad-Tree representingÂ grid.

A Quad-Tree is a tree data structure in which each internal node has exactly four children. Besides, each node has two attributes:

  • val: True if the node represents a grid of 1â€™s or False if the node represents a grid of 0â€™s. Notice that you can assign theÂ valÂ to True or False whenÂ isLeafÂ is False, and both are accepted in the answer.
  • isLeaf: True if the node is a leaf node on the tree or False if the node has four children.

We can construct a Quad-Tree from a two-dimensional area using the following steps:

  1. If the current grid has the same value (i.e allÂ 1'sÂ or allÂ 0's) setÂ isLeafÂ True and setÂ valÂ to the value of the grid and set the four children to Null and stop.
  2. If the current grid has different values, setÂ isLeafÂ to False and setÂ valÂ to any value and divide the current grid into four sub-grids as shown in the photo.
  3. Recurse for each of the children with the proper sub-grid.

If you want to know more about the Quad-Tree, you can refer to theÂ wiki.

Quad-Tree format:

You donâ€™t need to read this section for solving the problem. This is only if you want to understand the output format here. The output represents the serialized format of a Quad-Tree using level order traversal, whereÂ nullÂ signifies a path terminator where no node exists below.

It is very similar to the serialization of the binary tree. The only difference is that the node is represented as a listÂ [isLeaf, val].

If the value ofÂ isLeafÂ orÂ valÂ is True we represent it asÂ 1Â in the listÂ [isLeaf, val]Â and if the value ofÂ isLeafÂ orÂ valÂ is False we represent it asÂ 0.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Solve

åˆ†è§£

entry.content:
#Problem
Given an integer arrayÂ numsÂ and an integerÂ val, remove all occurrences ofÂ valÂ inÂ numsÂ in-place. The order of the elements may be changed. Then returnÂ the number of elements inÂ numsÂ which are not equal toÂ val.

Consider the number of elements inÂ numsÂ which are not equal toÂ valÂ beÂ k, to get accepted, you need to do the following things:

  • Change the arrayÂ numsÂ such that the firstÂ kÂ elements ofÂ numsÂ contain the elements which are not equal toÂ val. The remaining elements ofÂ numsÂ are not important as well as the size ofÂ nums.
  • ReturnÂ k.

The final sorted array should not be returned by the function, but instead beÂ stored inside the arrayÂ nums1. To accommodate this,Â nums1Â has a length ofÂ m + n, where the firstÂ mÂ elements denote the elements that should be merged, and the lastÂ nÂ elements are set toÂ 0Â and should be ignored.Â nums2Â has a length ofÂ n.

entry.title: Leetcode#87.Â Scramble String
entry.content:
Problem

We can scramble a string s to get a string t using the following algorithm:

  1. If the length of the string is 1, stop.
  2. If the length of the string is > 1, do the following:
    • Split the string into two non-empty substrings at a random index, i.e., if the string isÂ s, divide it toÂ xÂ andÂ yÂ whereÂ s = x + y.
    • RandomlyÂ decide to swap the two substrings or to keep them in the same order. i.e., after this step,Â sÂ may becomeÂ s = x + yÂ orÂ s = y + x.
    • Apply step 1 recursively on each of the two substringsÂ xÂ andÂ y.

Given two stringsÂ s1Â andÂ s2Â ofÂ the same length, returnÂ trueÂ ifÂ s2Â is a scrambled string ofÂ s1, otherwise, returnÂ false.

Example 1:

Example 2:

Example 3:

Constraints:

  • s1.length == s2.length
  • 1 <= s1.length <= 30
  • s1Â andÂ s2Â consist of lowercase English letters.

Solve

entry.title: Leetcode#62.Â Unique Paths
entry.content:
Problem

There is a robot on anÂ m x nÂ grid. The robot is initially located at theÂ top-left cornerÂ (i.e.,Â grid[0][0]). The robot tries to move to theÂ bottom-right cornerÂ (i.e.,Â grid[m - 1][n - 1]). The robot can only move either down or right at any point in time.

Given the two integersÂ mÂ andÂ n, returnÂ the number of possible unique paths that the robot can take to reach the bottom-right corner.

The test cases are generated so that the answer will be less than or equal toÂ 2 * 109.

Example 1:
